awd_titl_txt: RAPID: REU Site: A Virtual Research Experience in Macromolecular Structure and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID pandemic has caused closures of REU Sites in summer 2020. The situation continues this summer 2021 with some REU programs already posting cancellations. This RAPID proposal will mitigate the inadequate number of available opportunities for students. The University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), located in Chicago, Illinois, will support the training of seven students for eight weeks during the summer of 2021.  Research will be conducted online with faculty located in Chicago, Evanston (IL), and Dallas (TX). The students, who are from groups under-represented in science or from schools with limited research opportunities, will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. This program provides vital training, mentoring, and professional skills development to enable and encourage talented students to continue in degrees and careers in science, which is vital for the future of US science and the economy. Students will participate in full-time mentored research projects using state-of-the-art computer-based methods to advance our understanding of the structure and function of DNA, proteins and other macromolecules. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

	The scientific theme of the program is Macromolecular Structure and Function.  Faculty mentors come from UIC Departments of Biology, Physics, and Bioengineering, the University of Chicago Biological Sciences Collegiate Division, the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center Green Center for Systems Biology, and the Northwestern University Molecular Biosciences Department.  The computer-based projects include elucidating protein functional sites, conformational changes involved in aggregation, cellular targeting signals, and mechanisms of nutrient uptake. Program components include professional skills training in ethical issues, responsible conduct of research, diversity and inclusion, science careers, and oral and written scientific communication.  Participants will present their accomplishments at a Research Symposium.  More information is available by visiting /bios.uic.edu/profiles/jeffery-constance-j/, or by contacting the PI (Prof. Jeffery, cjeffery@uic.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 crisis eliminated most opportunities for undergraduate research experiences for more than a year. This loss particularly adversely impacted students from groups who were already under-represented in STEM because they were less likely to have access to other research and learning opportunities and often had significant added family commitments during the pandemic.  Undergraduate research opportunities are critical for keeping minority students in the STEM degree and career pipeline. The loss of these opportunities left the country at a great risk of losing talented students from pursuing degrees and careers in STEM, which could lead to a significant negative impact on the future of American science and the economy. Opportunities were needed immediately to keep minority students in the STEM learning and career pipeline. This RAPID-REU project addressed a severe and urgent need for high quality undergraduate research experiences and professional skills development at a time when many other opportunities had been lost due to the pandemic. The program provided 1) A mentored research experience in Macromolecular Structure and Function and 2) Training in professional skills that will assist the participants in pursuing a career in STEM.

The Macromolecular Structure and Function REU supported the training of seven students during the summer of 2021.  Research was conducted online with professors at four universities:  Constance Jeffery and Fatemeh Kashaghi at the University of Illinois at Chicago, Kimberly Reynolds and Milo Lin at the University of Texas Southwestern, Esmael Haddadian at the University of Chicago, and Heather Pinkett at Northwestern University.  To prepare participants for full participation, the first week included an orientation and workshops providing background information about current research methods in Macromolecular Structure and Function.  Students then participated in full-time mentored research projects using state-of-the-art computer-based methods to advance our understanding of the structure and function of DNA, proteins and other macromolecules.  The participants? poster titles illustrate the results from their research projects (undergraduates underlined):

Jorge Villa, E. Haddadian, ?Analysis of the Insulin Degrading Enzyme Conformational Changes Between Closed and Open State; A molecular Dynamics Study?

Jaynia Garcia, K. Rivera, J. Greenwood, H. Pinkett, ?Computational Docking Study of Substrate Binding Protein SapA?

Cesar Siete, N. Curtis, C. Jeffery, ?Proximity of RNA Binding Sites with Catalytic Features in Moonlighting Proteins?

Carolina Ortiz, C. Jeffery, N. Curtis, ?Structural Features of RNA Binding Sites in Moonlighting Proteins?

Amina Rizwan, J. McCormick, K. Reynolds, ?Are sector-connected surface sites involved in allosteric control of transport proteins??

KarlaGonz?lez-Cruz, F. Khalili-Araghi, ?Identifying Claudin Blockers Through Molecular Dynamics?

Andres Lozano, M. Lin, ?Characterization of Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation Through SUMO and SIM Protein Interactions?

Weekly group meetings, workshops, and other activities enabled participants to interact with each other, the PI, and our near-peer graduate student mentor.  Workshops provided professional skills training about Reading a Scientific Paper, How to Keep a Lab Notebook, Preparing and Delivering a Seminar, Writing Abstracts and Scientific Papers, Preparing and Presenting Scientific Posters, How to Give an Elevator Pitch, Applying to Graduate School, Science Careers, Ethical Issues, Diversity and Inclusion, and Responsible Conduct of Research.  Participants presented their accomplishments at a Research Symposium during the final week of the program. 

In addition to providing research experience and professional training for the participants, the program lead to additional products. Several research publications are in preparation that include results from participants? projects, as well as a publication about the REU. The project web site makes the orientation and workshop materials and the symposium abstract booklet available for other students interested in macromolecular structure and function or professional skills development.  These materials can also be used by other professors for training purposes and for developing similar research and training programs.  Each student participant prepared a scientific poster about his/her project that was printed so that they can share them with their home departments and present them at meetings.  Posters including results from student participants were also prepared and presented by host labs, including posters at the 2022 Biophysical Society and Protein Society meetings. Oral presentations resulting from the program included an invited seminar (via zoom) ?Various Ways to Pursue a Gap Year(s): An Overview? by Nicole Curtis, our near-peer mentor, for undergraduates at Loyola Marymount University, and Jaynia Garcia presented her research at the Southern California Conference for Undergraduate Research. Participation in this REU also helped student participants to prepare for the next stages in their research training and careers: Cesar Siete, Jaynia Garcia, and Carolina Ortiz were accepted into Post-Bac programs.

In summary, the REU program in Macromolecular Structure and Function provided students from groups who are under-represented in science with an experience integrating cutting-edge research and training, mentoring, and professional skills development to enable and encourage these talented students to continue in graduate school or professional school and a future career in science, which is vital for the future of US science and the economy.
